sp.p: Why how now my Lord? who do you call rogue? the Gentleman you name is my friend, if you were wise I should be angrie.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.l: Angrie with me? why dam me Sir, and you be;
Cut with your sword, it is not with me I tell you
As it was yesterday, I am flesht man, I.
Haue you any thing to say to me?

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: Nothing but this, how many doe you thinke, you haue slaine last night?

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: Why fiue, I neuer kill lesse.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: There was but foure: my Lord, you had best prouide your selfe and begon, three you haue slaine starke dead.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: You jest.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: T'is most true, Weltri'd is fled.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: Why let the Rorers meddle with me another time, as for flying, I scorne it, I kild 'em like a man; when did you euer see a Lord hang for any thing? we may kill whom we list, marry my conscience pricks me; ah plague a this drinke, what things it makes vs doe, I doe no more remember this now than a puppie-dogge.
sp.l: Oh bloodie Lord that art bedawb'd with gore,
Vaine world adiew, for I will rore no more.

sp.speaker: Bould
sp.p: Nay stay my Lord, I did but trie the tendernesse of your conscience, all this is nothing so, but to sweeten the tale (I haue for you) I foretold you this fain'd mischance.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: Is it a tale belonging to the Widdow?

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: I thinke you are a witch.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: My grand-mother was suspected.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: The Widdow has desired you by me to meete her to morrow morning at Church in some vnknowne disguise, least any suspect it, for quoth she,
sp.l: Long hath he held me fast in his moist hand,
Therefore I will be his in nuptiall band.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p:
Bould, I haue euer taken you to be my friend, I am very wise now, and valiant, if this be not true, dam-me Sir,
you are the sonne of a whore, and you lie, and I will make it good with my sword.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: I am, what e're you please Sir, If it be not true, I will goe with you to the Church my selfe, your disguise I haue thought on; the Widdow is your owne. Come, leaue your fooling.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.l: If this be true, thou little Boy,

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.l: So true, as thou tel'st to me,
To morrow morne when I haue the Widdow,
My deare friend shalt thou be.

div.stage: Enter MAID like the foote-boy: SELDOME with a couple of SERIEANTS, PITS, DONNER.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Sir, t'is most true and in this shall you be
vnlike to other Citizens that arrest
To vndoe Gentlemen: your clemencie heere
perchance saues two liues, one from the others sword,
The other from the Lawes; this morne they fight,
And though your debtor be a Lord, yet should he
Miscarrie, certainely your debt were lost.

sp.speaker: Seld.
sp.l: Do'st thou serue the Lord Proudly?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Sir, I do.

sp.speaker: Seld.
sp.l: Well, such a Boy as thou, is worth more money
Then thy Lord owes me, t'is not for the debt
I doe arrest him, but to end this strife,
Which both may loose my money and his life.

div.stage: Enter Lord PROVDLY with a riding rod.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: My Horse there, Z'oones I would not for the world
He should alight before me in the field,
My name and honor were for euer lost.

sp.speaker: Seld.
sp.l: Good morrow to your Honor, I doe heare
Your Lordship this faire morning is to fight,
And for your honor: Did you neuer see
The Play, where the fat Knight hight Old-castle,
Did tell you truly what this honor was?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Why, how now good man flat-cap, what d'ee lack?
Who doe you talke to, sirrha?

sp.speaker: 1. Serg.
sp.l: We arrest you.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Arrest me, rogue? I am a Lord ye curs, a Parliament man.

sp.speaker: 2. Serg.
sp.l: Sir, we arest you though.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: At whose suit?

sp.speaker: Seld.
sp.l: At mine, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Why thou base rogue, did not I set thee vp,
Hauing no stock, but thy faire shop and wise?

sp.speaker: Seld.
sp.l: Into my house with him.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Away with him, away with him.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: A plot, a trick by Heauen. See Ingens foote-boy, t'is by his Masters meanes, oh coward, slaue; i'le put in baile, or pay the debt.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: I, I, I, wee'll talke with you within— thrust him in.

div.stage: Enter INGEN looking on his sword and bending it, his brother like a Man.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: If I miscarrie Franck, I prithee see
All my debts paid, about fiue hundred pounds
Will fully satisfie all men, and my land
And what I else possesse, by natures right
And thy descent, Franck, I make freely thine.

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.l: I know, you doe not thinke I wish you dead
For all the benefit: besides, your spirit
So opposite to counsaile, to auert
Your resolution, that I saue my breath,
Which would be lost in vaine, to expire and spend
Vpon your foe, if you fall vnder him.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Franck, I protest you shall doe iniurie
Vnto my foe, and much disturbance to
Vnto my soule departing, die I heere
Fairely, and on my single enemies sword,
If you should not let him go off vntouch't.
Now by the Master of thy life and mine,
I loue thee Boy, beyond any example,
As well as thou do'st me, but should I goe
Thy second to the field, as thou dost mine,
And if thine enemie kild thee like a man,
I would desire, neuer to see him more,
But he should beare himselfe off with those wounds
He had receau'd from thee, for that time safe,
And without persecution by the Law,
For what hap is our foes, might be our owne,
And no mans iudgement, sits in Iustice place,
But weighing other mens as his owne case.

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.l: He has the aduantage of you being a Lord,
For should you kill him, you are sure to die,
And by some Lawyer with a golden tongue,
That cries for right, ten angels on his side;
Your daring meete him, cal'd presumption:
But kill he you, hee, and his noble friends
Haue such a golden snaffle for the jawes
Of man, deuouring Pithagorean Law,
Thei'le reyne her stubborne chaps, e'ne to her taile?
And though she haue yron teeth to meaner men,
So master her, that who displeasd her most,
She shall lie vnder like a tired jade,
For small boates on rough seas are quickly lost,
But ships ride safe, and cut what by they list.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Follow what may, I am resolu'd deare Brother,
This monster vallor, that doth feed on men,
Groanes in me for my reputation.
This charge I giue thee to, If I doe die,
Neuer to part from the yong Boy, which late
I entertain'd, but loue him for my sake:
And for my Mistresse the Ladie Honor,
Whom to deceiue, I haue deceiu'd my selfe.
If she be dead, pray God I may giue vp
My life a sacrifice on her, brothers sword;
But if thou liu'st to see her gentle brother,
If I be slaine, tell her I dy'de because
I had transgrest against her worthy loue.
This sword is not well mounted, lets see thine.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Your staying Sir, is in vaine, for my Lord Proudly,
Iust at his taking horse to meete you heere,
At Seldomes suit the Citizen, was arrested
Vpon an action of two hundred pounds,
I saw it Sir, t'is true.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Oh, scuruie Lord,
It had beene a cleanlier shift then this to haue had
It hinder'd by command, he being a Lord,
But I will finde him.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.l: You see, valiant Sir, I haue got loose
For all your stratagem, oh rogue are you there.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Most ignoble Lord.

div.stage: Ingen stabs Proud. in the left arme.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.l: Coward thou did'st this
That I might be disabled for the fight,
Or that thou mightst haue some excuse to shun me,
But t'is my left arme, thou hast lighted on.
I haue no second; heere are three of you,
If all doe murther me, your consciences
Will more then hang you, damn you; come prepare.

sp.speaker: In.
sp.l: Brother walk off, & take the boy away, is he hurt much?

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: Nothing or very little.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p: I'le bind your wound vp first, your losse of blood May sooner make you faint.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Ingen, thou art a worthy Gentleman, for this curtesie,
Go-too i'le saue thy life, come on Sir: hay,
I'le cut your codpeice point Sir, with this thrust,
And then downe goes your breeches.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Your Lordships merrie
I had like to haue spoild your cut-worke band.

div.stage: Enter MAID like a foote-boy running, BROTHER after him, Maid kneeles betwixt 'em.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Oh Master, hold your hand, my Lord hold yours,
Or let your swords meete in this wretched breast,
Yet you are both well, what blood you haue lost
Giue it as for the iniurie you did, and now be friends,

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: S'hart, t'is a louing rogue.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Kind Boy, stand vp, t'is for thy wound he bleeds,
My wrong is yet vnsatisfied.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Hence away it is a Sisters losse, that whets my sword.

sp.speaker: Mai.
sp.l: Oh stay, my Lord, behold your sister heere
Bleeding by your hand Seruant see your mistresse
Turn'd to thy seruant running by thy Horse,
Whose means it was to haue preuented this, but all in vaine.

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.l: Oh noble Ladie.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Most worthie patterne of all women kind.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.l: Ingen, I am satisfied, put vp your sword.
Sister, you must with me, I haue a husband
The Lord Fee-simple's father, old, but rich:
This Gentleman is no match for you; kneele not,
That portion of yours, I haue consum'd,
Thus marrying, you shall neuer come to want.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Oh I sweet my Lord, my brother do not force me,
To breake my faith or to a loathed bed.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Force you, he shall not, brother beare her hence,
Shee is my wife, and thou shalt finde my cause
Ten times improu'd now.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Oh, haue at you Sir.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Hold, hold for heauens sake, was e're wretched Lady
Put to this hazard? Sir, let me speake
But one word with him, and I'le goe with you,
And vndergoe, what euer you command.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.l: Doo't quickly, for I loue no whispering,
T'is strange to see you Madame with a sword,
You should haue come hither in your Ladies cloathes.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Well, as you please my Lord, you are witnesse, whatsoe're before
sp.l: Hath past betwixt vs: thus I doe vndoe.
Were not I mad to thinke thou could'st loue me
That would'st haue slain my Brother?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Sai'st true sister.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p: Oh thou faire creature! wilt thou be as false as other Ladies?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Thou art my example,
Ile kisse thee once, farewell for euer, come my Lord, now
Match me, with whom you please, a tumbler.
I must doe this, else had they fought againe.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Mine own best Sister, farewel Mr. Ingen.

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.l: Oh antient truth to be denied of no man,
An Eele by'th taile's held surer than a woman.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.l: SHee is not to be cast.

sp.speaker: Hus.
sp.l: It cannot be: had you a wife, and I were in your
case.

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.l: I would be hang'd euen at the chamber doore
Where I attempted, but i'le lay her flat.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.l: Why tell me truely, would it please you best,
To haue her remaine chast, or conquered.

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.l: Oh friend it would do me good at the heart
To haue her ouer come, shee do's so brag
And stand vpon her chastitie forsooth.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.l: Why then in plaine termes Sir, the fort is mine,
Your wife has yeelded, vp-tailes is her song,
The deed is done, come, now, be merrie man.

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.l: Is the deed done indeed? come, come, you jest,
Has my wife yeelded? is vptailes her song?
Faith come, in prose, how got you to the matter first, ha.
Pish, you are so bashfull now.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Why, by my troth i'le tell you, because you are my friend, otherwise you must note it is a great hurt to the art of whooremasterie to discouer, besides the skill was neuer mine o'th price.

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.l: Very good, on sir.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.l: At the first she was horrible stiffe against me, then
Sir I tooke her by the hand, which I kiss'd.

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.l: Good Sir.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: And I cal'd her pretie Rogue, and I thrust my finger betwixt her breasts, and I made lips; at last, I pul'd her by the chin to me, and I kist her.

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.p: Hum, very good.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: So at the first, she kist very strangely, close, & vntoward; then said I to her, thinke but vpon the wrongs, the intollerable wrongs, the rogue your Husband does you.

sp.speaker: Hus.
sp.p: I that was very good, what said she to you then sir?

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Nay, I went on. First quoth I, thinke how he hath vs'd you, left you no meanes, giuen all your clothes to his Punckes, struck you, turn'd your gray eies into black ones, but yet—

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.p: A pretie conceit.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Quoth I, these things are nothing in the Rascoll, thinke but what a base Whoore-master, the Rascoll is.

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.p: Did you call me Rascoll so often are you sure.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p:
Yes, and oftner, for said I, none comes amisse to
the rogue, I haue knowne him quoth I, doe three lowzie beggars vnder hedges in the riding of ten mile, and I swore this to.

sp.speaker: Hus.
sp.p: Twas verie well, but you did lie. On I pray.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.p: Pish, one must lie a little, now sir by this time shee began to kisse some what more openly, and familiarlie, her resistance began to slacken, and my assault began to stiffen, the more her Bulwarke decai'd, the more my batterie fortified, at last sir, a little fumbling being past to make the Conquest more difficult, shee perceauing my readines mounted, fals me flat vpon her backe, cries mee out aloud
sp.l: Ahlas I yeeld, vse me not roughly friend,
My fort, that like Troy towne, ten yeares hath stood
Beseig'd and shot at did remaine vnwon:
But now tis conquer'd. So the deede was done,

sp.speaker: Hus.
sp.l: Then came the hottest seruice. Forward with your tale sir.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Nay Caetera, quis neset, lassi requienimus ambo:
Proueniant medii sic mihi sape dies.

sp.speaker: Hus.
sp.p: Which is as much to say: I am a Cuckold, in all Languages, but sure tis not so, It is impossible my wife should yeeld.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.p: Hoyday, ene now, it was impossible she should hold out, and now it is impossible she should yeeld, stay you but heere & be an eare witnes to what followes, Ile fetch your wife. I know he will not stay.

sp.speaker: Hus.
sp.p: Good faith Sir but he will. I doe suspect some knauerie in this.
sp.l: Here will I hide my selfe, when thought as gone,
If they doe ought vnfitting I will call
Witnesse, and straight way sue a diuorce.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: I knew hee would not stay. Now noble Mistrisse,
I claime your promise.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: What was that good seruan

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: That you would lie with me.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: If with anie man,
But prithee first consider with thy selfe
If I should yeeld to thee, what a load thy Conscience
Would beare about it, for I wish quick thunder
May strike me, If I yet haue lost the truth,
Or whitenesse of the hand I gaue in Church,
And twill not be, thy happinesse (as thou thinkst)
That thou alone should'st make a woman fall,
That did resist all else, but to thy soule
A bitter Corasiue, that thou didst staine,
Vertue that else had stood immaculate,
Nor speake I this, as yeelding vnto thee,
For tis not in thy power, wert thou the sweet'st
Of natures Children, and the happiest,
To conquer me, nor in mine owne to yeeld,
And thus it is with euery pious wife.
Thy daylie railing at my absent Husband
Makes me indure thee worse, for let him doe
The most preposterous ill relishing things
To me, they seeme good, since my Husband does 'em,
Nor am I to reuenge or gouerne him,
And thus it should be with all vertuous Wiues.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Poxe a this vertue and this chastetie,
Doe you know faire Mistresse, a young Gentleman
About this towne cald Bould, where did he lie
Last night, sweet Mistris, oh oh, are you catch'd,
I saw him slip out of the house this morne,
As naked as this truth, and for this cause
I haue tould your Husband that you yeelded to me,
And he I warrant you, will blaze it throughly,
As good doe now then as bee thought to doe.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: No, twill not be yet, thou iniurious man,
How wilt thou right me in my Husbands thoughts,
That on a false surmise, and spight hast tould,
A tale to breed vncurable discontent?
Bould was that ould wench that did serue the Widdow,
and thinking by this way to gaine her loue
Mist of his purpose, and was thus cashier'd,
Nor cares shee to proclame it to the world.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Zoons, I haue wrong'd you Mistris. On my knees
I aske you pardon, and will neuer more,
Attempt your puritie, but neglect all things
Till that soule wrong I haue bred in your Knight
I haue expeld, and let your loues aright.

sp.speaker: Hus.
sp.l: Which now is done alreadie Madame wife,
Vpon my knees, with weeping eies, heau'd hands,
I aske thy pardon, oh sweet vertuous creature,
I prithee breake my head.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Rise, rise, Sir pray:
You haue done no wrong to me, at least I thinke so;
Heauen hath preuented all my iniurie,
I doe forgiue and marrie you a new.
Come, we are all inuited to the weddings,
The Ladie Honor to the old rich Connt.
Yong Bould vnto another Gentlewoman,
We and the Widdow are inuited thither,
Embrace and loue, henceforth more really,
Not so like worldlings.

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.l: Heere then ends all strife
Thus false friends are made true, by a true wife.

div.head: Actus quinti Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter old COVNT wrapt in furs, the Ladie HONOR drest like a Bride, the Lord PROVD. WEL-TRI'D, BOVLD, leading FEE-SIMPLE like a Ladie masqu'd, HVSBAND, WIFE, SVBTLE with a letter, WIDDOW, to them BROTHER, SELDOM, and his wife.

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.l: HEalth and all joy vnto this faire assemblie,
My brother, who last tide is gone for France,
A branch of willow feathering his hat,
Bad me salute you Ladie, and present you
With this same letter written in his blood,
He prayes no man, for his sake euermore
To credit woman, nor no Ladie euer
To beleiue man, so either sexe shall rest
Vniniur'd by the other, this is all, and this I haue deliuer'd.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I and well, you pronounce rarely did you neuer play?

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.l: Yes, that I haue, the foole, as some Lords doe.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.l: Set forward there.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Oh, oh, oh, a pox a this cold.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.l: A cold a this poxe you might say, I am afeard.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: How full of ghastly wounds this letter shewes, oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Looke to my sister.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: S'hart the Ladie swoons.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Strong-water there.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.l: If strong breath would recouer her, I am for her.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Ahlas good Ladie, hum, hum, hum. coughs perpetually

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.l: He has fet her againe with coughing.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Conuey me to my bed send for a Priest
And a Physition, your Bride I feare,
In stead of Epithalamions shall neede
A Dirge, or Epitaph, oh lead me in,
My bodie dies for my soules periur'd sinne.

div.stage: Exit Maid, Grace, Wife, Husb. Subtle.

sp.speaker: Bould
sp.l: Hymen comes towards vs in a mourning robe.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.l: I hope friend, we shall haue the better day.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.l: I'le fetch the Parson and Physition

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.l: They are both readie for you.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.l: Madam, this is the Gentlewoman.
Who something bashfull does desire your pardon, that shee
Does not vnmasque.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Good Master Wel-tri'd, I would not buie her face, and for her manners if they were worse, they shall not displease me.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: I thanke your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: Looke, how the old Asse my father stands, he looks like the Beare in the play, he has kil'd the Ladie with his verie sight as God helpe me, I haue the most to do to forbeare vnmasquing me, that I might tell him his owne, as can be.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.l: Fie, by no meanes.
The Widdow comes towards you.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Oh, oh, oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Seruant, God giue you joy, and Gentlewoman,
Or Ladie as full joy, I wish to you,
Nor doubt that I will hinder you, your loue,
But heere am come to doe all curtesie
To your faire selfe, and husband that shall be.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.l: I thank you heartilie.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.l: S'hart, speak smaller man.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.l: I thanke you heartilie.

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.p: You're going to this geere to Mr. Bould, vm, vm, vm.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: Not to your couching geere my Lord, though I be not so olde, or rich as your Lordship, yet I loue a yong wench as well.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: As well, as my Lord, nay by my faith, that you do not, loue a yong wench as well as he, I wonder you will be vnmannerly to say so.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: Faith Master Wel-tri'd, troth is I loue them well, but they loue not me, vm, vm, vm, you see, what ill luck, I haue with them, vmp, vmp, vmp, a poxe a this cold still say I.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Where got you this cold my Lord? it can get in no where that I can see, but at your nostrels, or eies, all the other parts are so barricado'd with furre.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: It got in at his eies, and made that birdlime there where cupids wings doe hang intangled.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Is this your wife, that (vm, vm, vm) shall be, Ma. Bould, i'le be so bould as kisse her.

div.stage: Count. sits in a chaire and fals a sleepe.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: Sir, forbeare, I haue one bould enough to kisse my lips, oh olde coxcombe, kisse thine owne naturall sonne, t'is worse then a Iustices lying with his own daughter, but Mr. Wel-tri'd when will the Widdow breake this matter to me?

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Not till the very close of all, she dissembles it yet, because my Lord your Father is heere, and her other suitor Bould.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.l: That's all one, he's o'th plot a my side:

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: T'is needlesse Master Bould, but I will doe
Any thing you require to satisfie you,
Why should you doubt, I will forbid the banes,
For so your friend, heere tould me? I should rather
Doubt that you will not marrie.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Madam by heauen, as fully I am resolu'd to marry now,
And will to, if you doe not hinder it,
As euer louer was, only because
The World has taken notice of some passage
Twixt you and me, and then to satisfie
My sweet heart heere, who poore soule is a feard,
To haue some publike disgrace put vpon her,
I doe require some small thing at your hands.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Well, I will doe it and this professe besides,
Married, you shall as welcome be to mee
As mine owne brother, and your selfe faire Ladie,
Euen as my selfe, both to my boord, and bed.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.l: Ah, ah, how like you that?

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: Now she begins, abundant thanks vnto your widdow-hood.
sp.l: Z'oones my Fathers a sleepe on's wedding day,
I wonder'd where his cough was all this while.

div.stage: Enter INGEN like a Doctor: A PARSON, BROTHER, PROVDLY, SELDOME, MRIS. SELD. HVSBAND, WIFE, and SVBTLE.

sp.speaker: Ingen.
sp.l: I pray forbeare the chamber, noise does hurt her.
Her sickenesse I ghesse rather of the minde
Than of her bodie, for her pulse beates well,
Her vitall functions not decaid a whit,
But haue their naturall life and operation.
My Lord, be cheer'd, I haue an ingredient about me,
Shall make her well I doubt not.
In Master Parson, it shall be yours I pray,
The soules Physition should haue still the way.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: How cheeres she pray?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: In troth exceeding ill.

sp.speaker: Ms. Seld.
sp.l: A verie weake woman indeed she is, and surely
I thinke cannot scape it.

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.l: Did you marke how she ey'de the Physition?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Oh God I, she is very loath to die.

sp.speaker: Ms. Seld.
sp.l: I that's n'ere the better signe, I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.l: And when the Parson came to her, she turn'd away,
And still let the Physicion hold her by the hand.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.p: But see what thought the Bride-groome takes, my conscience knowes now, this is a most praeposterous match, yet for the commoditie, we winck at all inconueniencie. My Lord, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Vmp, vmp, vmp, I beshrow you for waking of me, now shall I haue such a fit of coughing, hum, hum—

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
Oh haplesse wife, that shall haue thee, that either
must let thee sleepe continually, or be kept waking her selfe by the cough.

sp.speaker: Wid
sp.l: You haue a proper Gentleman to your sonne, my
Lord, he were fitter for this yong Ladie than you.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.l: D'ee marke that againe?

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.l: Oh sweet widdow.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: He a wife, he a fooles head of his owne.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.l: No, of my Fathers.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: What should he doe with a vmp, vmp?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: What with a cough? why he would spit, and that's more than you can doe.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.p: Your bride my Lord is dead.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Marrie, e'ne God be with her, griefe will not helpe it, vmp, vmp, vmp.

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.l: A most excellent spouse.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: How fares she Mr. Doctor. Z'oons, whats here
Bould, Widdow, Wel-tri'd, Fee-simple, hoy-day.
Husband, Wife, Seldome, Ms. Seld. Subtle: how now?

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: Looke, looke, the Parson joynes the Doctors hand & hers; now the Do. kisses her by this light.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: Now goes his gowne off, hoy-day, he has read breeches on: Z'oones, the Physition is got Pistols for Bro. o'th top of her, be like it is the mother she has, harke the bed creakes.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: S'hart, the doores fast, break 'em open, we are betrai'd.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: No breaking open doores, he that stirs first
I'le pop a leaden pill into his guts.
Shall purge him quite away, no hast good friends,
When they haue done (what's fit) you shall not neede
To breake the doore, thei'l open it them selues.

div.stage: A curtaine drawne, a bed discouer'd, Ingen with his sword in his hand, and a Pistoll, the Ladie in a peticoate, the Parson.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Thy blood base villain shal answere this
sp.stage: the Bro. set back to back
sp.l: I'le dye thy nuptiall bed in thy hearts gore.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Come, come, my Lord, t'is not so easily done,
You know it is not. For this my attempt
Vpon your sister, before God and man
She was my wife, and n'ere a bed-rid gowt
Shall haue my wench, to get diseases on.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Well mai'st thou tearme her so that has consented,
Euen with her will to be dishonor'd.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Not so, yet haue I lyen with her.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: But first (witnesse this Priest) we both were married,

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.l: True it is Domine.
Their contract's run into a marriage,
And that my Lord into a carriage.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I will vndoe thee Priest.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.l: 'Tis to late,
I'm vndone alreadie, wine and Tobacco, I defie thee
Thou temporall Lord, perdy thou neuer shalt
Keepe me in jayle, and hence springs my reason,
My act is neither Felonie nor Treason.

sp.speaker: Fee.
sp.l: I sir, but you do not know, what kindred she may haue.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Come, come, there is no remedie.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: And weigh't right in my opinion my honor'd Lord,
And euery bodies else, this is a match,
Fitter ten thousand times, than your intent.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Most certaine t'is.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Besides, this Gentleman your brother in law well parted, and faire mean'd, and all this come about (you must conceiue) by your owne sisters wit as well as his.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Come, come, t'is but getting of me knighted my
Lord, and I shall become your Brother well enough.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Brother your hand, Lords may haue projects still,
But there's a greater Lord, will haue his will.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: This is dispatcht. Now Madam is the time,
For I long to be at it, your hand sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.l: Now, boyes.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: My Lord, and Gentlemen, I craue your witnesse
To what I now shall vtter. 'Twixt this Gentleman
There has beene some loue passages and my selfe,
Which heere I free him, and take this Ladie.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.l: Law ye, and take this Ladie.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Which with a mothers loue, I giue to him,
And wish all joy may crowne their marriage.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.l: Nay Madame, yet she is not satisfied.
Bould giues her a ring, and she puts it on her thumb.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Further, before yee all I take this ring
As an assumpsit, by the vertue of which
I bind my selfe in all my lands and goods,
That in his choice, i'le be no hinderance:
Or by forbidding banes, or claiming him
My selfe for mine, but let the match goe on
Without my check, which he intendeth now.
And once againe I say, I bind my selfe.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Then once againe, I say, widdow thou'rt mine:
Priest marrie vs, this match I did intend,
Yee are all witnesses, if thou hinder it,
Widdow your lands and goods are forfeit mine.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Ha, nay take me to, since there's no remedie,
Your Widdow (without goods) sels scuruilie.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Whoop, God giue you joy.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: S'light, I am cozend of all sides, I had good hope of the Widdow my selfe, but now I see euerie bodie leaues me sauing vm, vm, vm.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: 'Troth my Lord, & that will sticke by you I warrant.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: But how Sir, shall we salue this Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Hang her whoore.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.l: Fie, you are too vnciuill.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.l: Whoore in thy face, I doe defie thy taunts.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Nay hold faire Ladie, now I thinke vpon't.
The old Count has no wife, lets make a match.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: If he be so contented.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: With al my heart.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Then kisse your Spouse.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: S'foot she has a beard: how now, my sonne?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: T'is the Lord Fee-simple.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: Father, lend me your sword, you and I are made a couple of fine fooles, are we not? If I were not valiant now, and meant to beate 'em all, heere would lie a simple disgrace vpon vs, a Fee-simple one indeed, marke now what i'le say to 'em, d'ee heare my Masters, Dam-me, yee are all the sonne of a whoore, and ye lie, and I will make it good with my sword, this is cal'd Roaring Father.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.l: I'le not meddle with you Sir.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: You are my blood.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.l: And I flesht you, you know.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: And I haue a charge comming, I must not fight now.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.l: Has either of you any thing to say to me?

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.l: Not we Sir.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: Then haue I something to say to you. Haue you any thing to say to me?

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.l: Yes marrie haue I Sir.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: Then I haue nothing to say to you, for that's the fashion, Father if you will come away with your cough, doe? Let me see how many challenges must I get writ: You shall heere on me beleiue it.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.l: Nay, wee'le not now part angrie, stay the Feasts
That must attend the weddings, you shall stay.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: Why, then all friends, I thought you would not haue had the manners to bid vs stay dinner neither.

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.l: Then all are friends, and Ladie, wife, I crowne
Thy vertues with this wreath, that 'tmay be said,
There's a good wife.

div.stage: They set Girlonds on their heads.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: A Widdow.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: And a Maid.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Yet mine is now approu'd the happiest life,
Since each of you hath chang'd to be a wife.
